content.description:
The table below shows the level of household savings at various levels of disposable income in a country.

Savings Disposable Income <math alttext="$2,000" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>$2</mtext><mtext>,000</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$10,000 " display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>$10</mtext><mtext>,000</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$2,200" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>$2</mtext><mtext>,200</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$12,000" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>$12</mtext><mtext>,000</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Based on the data on savings and disposable income in the table above, what are the income tax multiplier and the spending multiplier?

choices.label: The tax multiplier is <math alttext="negative 0.1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the spending multiplier is 0.9.
The tax multiplier is 0.2 and the spending multiplier is <math alttext="negative 0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The tax multiplier is <math alttext="negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the spending multiplier is 8.
The tax multiplier is <math alttext="negative 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the spending multiplier is 10.
The tax multiplier is 10 and the spending multiplier is <math alttext="negative 1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The tax multiplier is <math alttext="negative 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the spending multiplier is 10.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an economic concept, principle, or model using quantitative data or calculations.
